questions.text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria?
questions.solution:
Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria.

The drugs with clinically important gametocidal activity (against all species) are:

  • High activity:
    • Artemisinins
    • Primaquine
  • Low to moderate activity:
    • Chloroquine
    • Quinine
    • Atovaquone/proguanil
  • No activity:
    • Mefloquine
    • Pyrimethamine
    • Sulfadoxine
    • Tetracycline

questions.text: Correct pairing of drug and its mechanism of action among the following is?
questions.solution:
Rituximab is an anti CD20 monoclonal antibody.

  • Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that targets the CD20 B-cell antigen. CD20 is found on cells from the pre–B cell stage through its terminal differentiation to plasma cells and is expressed on 90% of B-cell neoplasms.
  • Monoclonal antibody binding to CD20 generates transmembrane signals that produce autophosphorylation and activation of serine/tyrosine protein kinases, induction of c-Myc oncogene expression, and expression of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules.
  • Rituximab is approved as a single agent for relapsed indolent lymphomas and significantly enhances response and survival in combination with chemotherapy for the initial treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma(DLBCL).
  • It remains effective in patients who relapse after initial treatment with rituximab-based combinations.
  • Rituximab improves response rates when added to combination chemotherapy for other indolent B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas (NHLs), including CLL, mantle cell lymphoma, Waldenström macroglobulinemia, and marginal zone lymphomas.

The EGFR belongs to the ErbB family of transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinases also known as ErbB1 or HER1 (human EGFR 1). EGFR is essential for the growth and differentiation of epithelial cells.

Two separate classes of drugs that target the EGFR pathway are important in the therapy of solid tumors:

  1. Monoclonal antibodies recognize the extracellular domain of the EGFR, inhibit ligand-induced signaling, and can elicit an immune response. Cetuximab is a recombinant, chimeric human/mouse IgG1 antibody that binds to EGFR and prevents ligand-dependent signaling and receptor dimerization, thereby blocking cell growth and survival signals. It is used to treat patients with metastatic colon cancers and Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma(HNSCC).
  2. Protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors bind to the intracellular kinase domain and inhibit the enzymatic function of an EGFR. Erlotinib is a reversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for advanced non-small cell lung cancer(NSCLC) with mutant EGFR and advanced pancreatic cancer in combination with gemcitabine.

Trastuzumab is a humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody of HER2-human epidermal growth factor receptor 2, inhibiting hetero- and homodimerization and signal transduction. It is approved for HER2-overexpressing breast and gastric cancer.

questions.text: The drug efavirenz inhibits
questions.solution:
The drug efavirenz inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase. It is an NNRTI.

There are five classes of drugs in combination can be termed antiretro viral therapy (ART), combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) or highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

Antiretroviral drugs are classified by the phase of the retrovirus life cycle that the drug inhibits.

Antiretroviral drugs:

Nucleoside/Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors:

Mechanism: Nucleoside/Nucleotide analogs which inhibit reverse transcriptase.

Zidovudine

Didanosine

Stavudine

Zalcitabine

Lamivudine

Abacavir

Tenofovir disoproxil, Tenofovir alafenamide,

Emtricitabine

Nonnucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors: 

Mechanism: Inhibit reverse transcriptase by binding to an allosteric site of the enzyme.

Nevirapine

Efavirenz

Delavirdine

Etravirine

Rilpivirine

Protease Inhibitors:

Mechanism: Block the viral protease enzyme necessary to produce mature virions upon budding from host membrane.

Saquinavir

Indinavir

Ritonavir

Nelfinavir

Amprenavir

Lopinavir

Atazanavir(1st line)

Fosamprenavir

Tipranavir

Darunavir(1st line)

Entry Inhibitors:

Mechanism: interfere with binding, fusion, and entry of HIV -1 to cell by blocking a target.

Maraviroc works by targetting CCR5, a coreceptor located on human helper T-cells

Enfuvirtide

Maraviroc

Integrase Inhibitors:

Mechanism: Inhibit the viral enzyme integrase, which is responsible for the integration of viral DNA into the DNA of the infected cell.

Raltegravir

Elvitegravir

Dolutegravir

questions.text: Which among the following is a motilide?
questions.solution:
The name "motilide" refers to a motilin-like macrolide. The effects of motilin can be mimicked by erythromycin.

Erythromycin induces phase III migrating motor complex.

It has multiple effects on upper GI motility, increasing lower esophageal pressure and stimulating gastric and small-bowel contractility. However, it has little or no effect on colonic motility.

Erythromycin is used as a prokinetic agent in patients with diabetic gastroparesis, where it can improve gastric emptying in the short term.

Rapid development of tolerance (~28 days) to erythromycin, possibly by downregulation of the motilin receptor, and antibiotic effects (undesirable in this context) limit the use of this drug as a prokinetic agent.

A standard dose of erythromycin for gastric stimulation is 1.5–3 mg/kg intravenous infusion every 6 h in a hospital setting or 125 mg orally every 12 h.

At doses higher than 3 mg/kg, it can produce a spastic type of contraction in the small bowel, resulting in cramps, impairment of transit, and vomiting.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with severe restlessness, palpitations, facial flushing, and sweating. The patient had an episode of dysentery 2 days prior and had been prescribed medication for that. The patient reports taking alcohol 2 hours after his medications. Which of the following drug does not cause similar effects?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing symptoms like restlessness and flushing after taking alcohol after medication is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the given drugs, ofloxacin is not associated with a disulfiram-like reaction.

Some important drugs which cause a disulfiram-like reaction are:

  • Metronidazole, Tinidazole
  • Some cephalosporins like cefoperazone
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like tolbutamide
  • Procarbazine

These drugs inhibit aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes unpleasant symptoms like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

questions.text: Which drug can be used for pain relief in a patient with the following barium swallow?
questions.solution:
Sildenafil citrate - PDE 5 inhibitor can be used for pain relief in diffuse esophageal spasm.

The image depicts Corkscrew / Rosary bead appearance of the esophagus, characteristically seen in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm.

The pathophysiology of the disease, at least in part, involves inadequate Nitric Oxide(NO) synthesis or impaired Degradation of NO.

Treatment:

Initial Therapy: Calcium Channel Blocker - CCB (Diltiazem)

Tri-Cyclic Antidepressants - TCA (Imipramine)

For resistant Cases:NO Donors (Sildenafil/Nitrates)

Botulinum Toxin.

questions.text: Treatment for the nutritional form of this disease includes:
questions.solution:
The image shows an X-Ray that is suggestive of Rickets. There is thickening and widening of the growth plate.

Stoss therapy is used to treat nutritional rickets.

Treatment of nutritional rickets is by :

Stoss therapy - 3 - 6 lakh international units of Vit D IM or Oral. Alternatively, Daily high dose Vit. D orally - 2000-5000 IU Day, over 4-6 weeks -> followed by 400 IU per day with calcium supplements for 2-4 months.

Hypophosphatemic Rickets is treated with Joule’s Solution ( Dibasic Sodium Phosphate & Phosphoric Acid).

Renal Tubular Acidosis associated Rickets is treated with Shohl’s Solution ( Citric Acid & Sodium Citrate), Bicarbonate and Phosphate supplementation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a 5th generation cephalosporin?
questions.solution:
Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin, which exhibits broad-spectrum activity against Gram-positive bacteria, including MRSA and extensively-resistant strains, such as vancomycin-intermediate S. aureus (VISA), heteroresistant VISA (hVISA), and vancomycin-resistant S. aureus (VRSA).

Ceftobiprole is another 5th generation Cephalosporin.

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male patient with congestive heart failure as a maintenance dose to gradually digitalize him. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The dosing rate in this patient is 60 ng/min.

The oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70% (F = 0.7) and the required target plasma concentration (Cp) is 0.70 ng/mL. CL is the clearance of digoxin which is 60 mL/min.

Hence, the appropriate dose rate for this patient can be calculated as:

Dosing rate = Target Cp x CL/F

= [0.70 ng/mL × 60 mL/min] ÷ [0.7]

= 60 ng/min

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about tramadol?

choices.text: Maximum recommended daily dose is 400 mg
Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone
For mild-to-moderate pain, morphine is more effective than tramadol
Peak action is seen within 2-3 hours and lasts for about 6 hours

questions.solution:
For the treatment of mild-to-moderate pain, tramadol is as effective as morphine or meperidine. However, for the treatment of severe or chronic pain, tramadol is less effective.

Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog that acts as a mu-opioid receptor agonist. It also acts by inhibiting the uptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. The action peaks within 2–3 hours of oral dosing. The duration of analgesia is about 6 hours.

The maximum recommended daily dose is:

  • 400 mg for adults
  • 300 mg in patients >75 years old
  • 200 mg for patients with low creatinine clearance

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, dizziness, dry mouth, sedation, headache and respiratory depression. Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone. Tramadol can exacerbate seizures in patients with predisposing factors. Tramadol should be avoided in patients taking MAO inhibitors, SSRIs, or other drugs that lower the seizure threshold.

Clinical relevance: Precipitation of withdrawal necessitates that tramadol is tapered prior to discontinuation.

Related Pearl: Classification of opioids based on their action on opioid receptors

questions.text: The lab report of a 35 year old lady who underwent a medical checkup suggests dyslipidemia. She has a past medical history of peptic ulcer disease. Also 2 months back, she had severe pain in her great toe which was cured temporarily by taking NSAIDs. She has been taking statins for past 1 month. Which of the below drugs is absolutely contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Niacin would be absolutely contraindicated for the lady presenting with the above clinical history. 

Contraindications to niacin are:

  • Pregnancy
  • Concurrent use with statin - causes myopathy
  • History of peptic ulcer disease
  • Gout - is a relative contraindication

Other options:

Option A- Ezetimibe in combination with statin results in further reduction of low density lipoproteins (LDL) cholesterol. However this combination should not be used in pregnant women. Ezetimibe should also not be used along with bile acid sequestrants as they inhibit its absorption.

Option B- Cholestyramine is contraindicated is severe hypertriglyceridemia (Note: since the dyslipidemia in the question is not specific, this cannot be the answer).

Option C- Evolocumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/Kexin type 9 (PCSK9). It is contraindicated in those with hypersensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetics is an amide?
questions.solution:
Prilocaine is a local anesthetic that is classified as an Amide.

All the other drugs are classified as esters.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Methacholine?

choices.text: It is used for diagnosis of bronchial airway hyperreactivity
It is more resistant to hydrolysis compared to cholinesterase
It has a greater duration of action than ACh

questions.solution:
Methacholine has a predominantly muscarinic effect with only minor nicotinic actions, the former manifest most clearly in the cardiovascular system.

Methacholine is administered by inhalation for the diagnosis of bronchial airway hyperreactivity in patients who do not have clinically apparent asthma.

It is a synthetic choline ester that differs from ACh chiefly in its greater duration and selectivity of action. Its action is more prolonged because the added methyl group increases its resistance to hydrolysis by cholinesterases.

questions.text: Coadministration of lenalidomide with which other drug increases the risk for thrombosis?
questions.solution: Lenalidomide and thalidomide increase the risk for thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis, stroke, and myocardial infarction, which occur with increased frequency in combination with glucocorticoids and with anthracyclines.

questions.text: Low dose aspirin should be used with caution in a few patients with co-morbidities. True statement among the following is

choices.text: In diabetics because it can cause hyperglycemia
In children with viral disease because of the risk of acute renal failure
In gout because it can increase serum uric acid
In pregnancy, because of high risk of teratogenicity

questions.solution:
Aspirin at lower doses (<2 g/day) causes urate retention and block the effect of uricosuric drugs.

At intermediate doses (2-3 g/day), there is no effect on urate levels.

Only at high doses (>5 g/day), there is uricosuric effect but such large doses have poor tolerability.

Aspirin use is associated with Reye’s syndrome which is a rare form of hepatic encephalopathy seen in children having a viral disease (Option B).

Low dose aspirin use is not associated with hyperglycemia but can cause hypoglycemia in diabetic patients that warrants caution (Option A).

In pregnancy, the use of aspirin is associated with low birth weight and perinatal complications but not with a high risk of teratogenicity (Option D).

questions.text: The inhibition of hydrochloric acid secretion by omeprazole occurs within an hour, reaches a peak at 2 hours, and plateaus by the 4th day. After how many days will the secretion gradually normalize after stopping the drug?
questions.solution:
The secretion resumes normally in 3-4 days of stopping the drug when new proton pumps are synthesized.

Omeprazole after absorption enters into the systemic circulation, after which it diffuses into the parietal cells and accumulates in the acidic canaliculi.

Inside canaliculi, it is activated by proton catalyzed the formation of a tetracyclic sulfenamide that irreversibly inhibits H+/K+ ATPase.

Inhibition of HCl secretion occurs within 1 hour and reaches a maximum at 2 hrs.

The inhibition gradually increases over daily dosing and reaches a plateau after 4 days (80-98% inhibition).

The secretion resumes gradually over 3-4 days of stopping the drug when new proton pumps are synthesized.

questions.text: The most common complication of loop diuretic
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is the most common complication of loop diuretics.

  • Degree of Hypokalemia depends on the duration of action of the drug – longer acting drugs have higher risk.
  • Presents with - weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps; cardiac arrhythmias are the serious complications.
  • Hypokalaemia can be prevented and treated by:
    • High dietary K+ intake
    • Supplements of KCl (24–72 mEq/day)
    • Concurrent use of K+ sparing diuretics

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ketorolac?

choices.text: It's analgesic action is equal to morphine in post-operative pain
It is used as a pre anaesthetic medication

questions.solution:
Analgesic action of ketorolac is equal to morphine in post-operative pain

Ketorolac, an NSAID is an aryl acetic acid derivative with the following properties

  • It has mild anti-inflammatory action but is a potent analgesic (Option A). In postoperative pain reduction, the efficacy of ketorolac is comparable to morphine. Many studies have concluded that the analgesic action of ketorolac is equivalent to morphine. 
  • It does not interact with the opioid receptors and is therefore free of the opioid side effects (Option D)
  • It is mainly used in postoperative pain relief (Option C)

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and a recent history of diarrhea. He has associated tenderness over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the management of the CT finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, abdominal pain, a recent history of diarrhea, and an abdominal CT showing a moderate-sized abscess in the right liver lobe is suggestive of an amebic liver abscess. It is an extra-intestinal infection caused by Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating this condition. 

Amebic liver abscess follows intestinal amebiasis. However, a history of diarrhea may not always be present as most patients remain asymptomatic carriers. In patients presenting with the above symptoms, stool examination, serological tests, and radiological imaging help to confirm the diagnosis. 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating invasive amebiasis like an amebic liver abscess. It is a nitroimidazole compound and is a highly active tissue amebicide. Tinidazole, which is another longer-acting imidazole, is also highly effective for the management of this condition. Other tissue amebicides include secnidazole, satranidazole and ornidazole.

Metronidazole is also effective against other anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. It is used in the management of giardiasis, trichomoniasis, anaerobic bacterial infections (e.g., pelvic or abdominal abscesses following surgery), pseudomembranous enterocolitis, and Helicobacter pylori gastritis.

Adverse effects include gastrointestinal manifestations like anorexia, nausea, and a metallic taste. It is known for its ability to produce a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol. Metronidazole can decrease the renal elimination of lithium and potentiate its toxicity. It may also cause significant bleeding in patients on warfarin therapy.

Other options:

Iodoquinol (Option B), paromomycin (Option C), and diloxanide furoate (Option D) are luminal amebicides. They are poorly absorbed and thus reach high concentrations in the bowel and are used in the management of intestinal amebiasis. They are also indicated for invasive amebiasis. However, their role is to eradicate cysts and prevent further transmission. They would not have any direct effect on the extraintestinal liver abscess as seen in this case.

Related Pearl: Difference between pyogenic and amebic liver abscess

Clinical features

Pyogenic abscess

Amebic abscess

Age

>50 years

20–40 years

Male:Female ratio

1.5:1

10:1

Solitary vs multiple

Solitary 50%

Solitary 80%

Location

Right lobe

Right lobe

Travel to endemic area

No

Yes

Alcohol

Common

Common

Most common symptom

Fever with chills

Abdominal pain

Most common lab abnormality

Elevated ALP

Elevated ALP

Jaundice and elevated bilirubin

More common

Less common

Diagnosis

Positive blood culture

Positive antiamebic antibodies

 ALP: alkaline phophatase

questions.text: Maximum incidence of phototoxicity is associated with:
questions.solution: Among fluoroquinolones, Sparfloxacin has maximum incidence of phototoxicity.

questions.text: Tolerance occurs to all actions of morphine except:
questions.solution: Tolerance develops to most of the effects of morphine except miosis, constipation and convulsions.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs doesn’t cause hypoglycemia:
questions.solution:
• Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor and hence does not cause Hypoglycemia.
  • Reduces conversion of starch and disaccharides to monosaccharides.
  • Reduces postprandial hyperglycemia.
  • Since it doesn’t enhance the release of insulin, hypoglycemia doesn’t occur.

NOTE: Metformin also does not cause hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemia during biguanide therapy is essentially unknown. These agents are therefore more appropriately termed “euglycemic” agents.

questions.text: Which of the following antiepileptic drug does not act via inhibition of sodium channels:
questions.solution: Vigabatrin is a GABA transaminase inhibitor and has no effect on sodium channels.

questions.text: The drug not acting on tubulin is:
questions.solution:
Bleomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic acting by formation of free radicals and causing DNA strand breakage.

Microtubule damaging agents are:

  • Vincristine (Oncovin)
  • Vinblastine
  • Vinorelbine
  • Paclitaxel
  • Docetaxel
  • Estramustine

questions.text: Which of the following antitubercular drug is bacteriostatic:
questions.solution: Ethambutol is the only bacteriostatic drug among the first line antitubercular drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following antiglaucoma medications is unsafe in infants?
questions.solution:
The use of brimonidine is unsafe in infants. It is an alpha-2 agonist that can cross the blood-brain barrier. This may result in CNS depression and apnoea in neonates. Therefore it is contraindicated in children less than 2 years.

α2 agonists, through the activation of G-protein coupled receptor activation, inhibit the activity of adenylate cyclase. This reduces cAMP and hence reduces aqueous humor production by ciliary action.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was administered penicillin intravenously for Anthrax disease. Within 5 minutes, he developed generalized urticaria, swelling of lips, hypotension, and bronchospasm. The 1st choice drug to administer is
questions.solution:
Generalized urticaria, swelling of lips, hypotension, and bronchospasm suggests that the patient is developing anaphylactic shock. Epinephrine injection administered intramuscularly is the preferred choice in anaphylactic shock. Epinephrine is a powerful bronchodilator and it is a potent vasopressor.

Antihistamines have only an adjuvant role in anaphylactic shock and are not routinely used in emergency cases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman had diabetes mellitus that was not controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. She was started on short-acting insulin to prevent post-prandial glycemia. Which of the following drug would have been used?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, insulin aspart is a short-acting insulin that has better control of meal time hyperglycemia and lower rates of postprandial hypoglycemic events. 

The short-acting insulin analogs are absorbed more rapidly from subcutaneous sites and should be injected 15 min or less before a meal. When used to treat glycemia after meals, the short-acting analogs have lower rates of hypoglycemia and improved A1c levels. It has rapid absorption and a shorter duration of action due to instantaneous dissociation into monomers. Short-acting insulin analogs are:

  • Insulin lispro is identical to human insulin except at positions B28 and B29.
  • Insulin aspart is formed by the replacement of proline at B28 with aspartic acid, reducing self-association.
  • Insulin glulisine is formed when glutamic acid replaces lysine at B29 and lysine replaces asparagine at B3.

Regular insulin has slow absorption following subcutaneous injection and should be injected 30–45 min before a meal. 

Short-acting insulins are used in the management of diabetes mellitus, diabetic ketoacidosis (regular insulin) and in non-ketotic hyperosmolar hyperglycemic coma.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text: Initial dose of edrophonium for diagnoisis of myasthenia gravis is_____________
questions.solution:
Edrophonium is used in Ameliorative test for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. An initial dose of 2mg is given as IV push over 15-30sec..

  • Initially, 2 mg is administered. If improvements of symptoms do not occur within 45 seconds, an additional 8 mg can be administered.
  • Improvement of strength unaccompanied by lingual fasciculations is a positive test.
  • Edrophonium is short-acting because
    • The binding site of edrophonium to acetylcholine esterase: choline subsite of the active center
    • No reaction with the enzyme: reversible binding only
    • Quaternary structure: rapid elimination

Edrophonium in Reversal of Nondepolarizing Neuromuscular Blockers:

  • 10 mg IV over 30-45 secs

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, severe abdominal pain, and dark-colored urine. She has a previous history of repeated hospital admission for similar complaints. A diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria was made after a detailed workup. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The administration of barbiturates is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

Acute intermittent porphyria is a disorder of heme synthesis, characterized by a deficiency of hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS).

Barbiturates are enzyme inducers and they result in the increased synthesis of porphyrins and subsequent precipitation of acute intermittent porphyria. The biochemical basis for the worsening of porphyria by barbiturates is the de-repression/induction of ALA synthase.

Barbiturates are metabolized by microsomal CYP450, a heme-protein oxidase system found in the liver. In patients with porphyria, barbiturates precipitate an attack of porphyria by the following mechanism:

 Barbiturates increase the synthesis of CYP450
 ↓
Enhanced consumption of heme
↓
A decrease in heme concentration in the liver 
↓
De-repression/induction of ALAS-1
↓
Increased synthesis of heme precursors
↓
Precipitation of porphyria


Other options:

Theophylline, chlorpromazine, and benzodiazepine are not contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating porphyria: "BOOST CHAP"

The mnemonic "BOOST CHAP" can be used to remember the drugs precipitating porphyria.

B: Barbiturates

O: OCPs

O: Orphenadrine

S: Sulphonamides

T: Tetracyclines

C: Chloramphenicol, carbamazepine

H: Halothane, Hydralazine

A: Alcohol

P: Phenytoin

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

(XLDPP)

(AIP)

(EPP)

(FECH)

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for chronic adrenal insufficiency is (in mg/day):
questions.solution:
The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for chronic adrenal insufficiency is 20 mg/day.

The treatment of chronic adrenal insufficiency (not in crisis) requires glucocorticoid replacement at a dose that replaces the physiologic daily cortisol production. This is achieved by administering an oral replacement dose of 15-25mg Hydrocortisone. 
A midpoint dose of 20mg is given in 2-3 divided doses: 10mg + 5mg + 5mg. 
Half the daily dose should be administered to all patients in the morning. This is to follow the normal circadian rhythm.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes flagellate pigmentation?
questions.solution:
Flagellate hyperpigmentation/flagellate erythema is a characteristic cutaneous reaction to treatment with bleomycin. 

Clinical features include multiple linear streaks (erythematous or hyperpigmented) at sites of trauma and generalized pruritus.

questions.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor approved for familial periodic paralysis
questions.solution:
Dichlorphenamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhbitor is approved for familial periodic paralysis. The mechanism for benefit is still unknown but most probable due to induction of metabolic acidosis. 

Chlorpheiramine is a first generation anti-histaminergic agent (Option A).

Diethylcarbamazine is an antifilarial agent (Option C).

Chloroprocaine is a local anesthetic (Option D).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male comes to the OPD requesting medications to quit smoking. He complains about feeling helpless and hopeless most of the time since years and also reports having suicidal ideations. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in this case is well motivated to quit smoking however the patient is suffering from depression and hence the drug of choice is Bupropion (depressed patient wishing to quit smoking).

  • A sustained-release preparation of the antidepressant bupropion improves abstinence rates among smokers and remains a useful option. However, Bupropion decreases the seizure threshold and should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures.
  • Varenicline, a partial agonist at the α4β2 subtype of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, reduces cigarette craving and improves long-term abstinence rates. It has high receptor affinity, thus blocking access to nicotine, so if the treated smoker relapses, there is hardly any reward, and abstinence is more likely to be maintained.
  • The nicotine withdrawal syndrome can be alleviated by nicotine replacement therapy (e.g., nicotine inhaler and nasal spray, nicotine gum or lozenge, or nicotine transdermal patch). These methods suppress the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal. However, most resume smoking over the ensuing weeks or months.
  • The cannabinoid CB1 receptor inverse agonist rimonabant improves abstinence rates and reduces the weight gain seen frequently in ex-smokers. It was found to be linked to depressive and neurologic symptoms and is not approved by the FDA.

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
Among atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone and amisulpride have a higher risk of galactorrhoea.

Tuberoinfundibular neurons project from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary. Dopamine is delivered in this region via the hypophyseal vessels. Dopamine binds to the D2 receptors present on the lactotropes in the anterior pituitary, and tonically inhibits the prolactin secretion from these cells. 

The more potent a D2 blocking drug is, the more likely it is to cause hyperprolactinemia. All first-generation antipsychotic drugs cause hyperprolactinemia due to their D2 blocking properties. Among the atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone, and amisulpride are associated with hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia can induce breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and infertility in women, and sexual dysfunction in men.

questions.text: Longest acting SSRI is
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is the longest acting SSRI.

Fluoxetine has plasma t1/2 of 48-72 hours.

It is metabolized to an active product, norfluoxetine, which may have plasma concentrations greater than those of fluoxetine.

The elimination half-life of norfluoxetine is about three times longer than fluoxetine (180 hours) and contributes to the longest half-life of all the SSRIs.

As a result, fluoxetine has to be discontinued 4 weeks or longer before an MAOI can be administered to mitigate the risk of serotonin syndrome.

questions.text: Following a kidney transplant, a 24-year-old male patient is placed on cyclosporine but after 48 hours complains of serious nausea and diarrhea and has a sudden increase in transaminases. You switch him to tacrolimus but nausea persists and he complains of getting dizzy and has dyspnea. Which of the following immunosuppressive agents would be an alternate drug in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Mycophenolate mofetil is the immunosuppressive agent that would be an alternate drug in this scenario indicated as a prophylaxis for transplant rejection. 

Mycophenolate mofetil is a prodrug that is rapidly converted to mycophenolic acid. It is a selective, non-competitive, reversible inhibitor of inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), an important enzyme in the de novo pathway of guanine nucleotide synthesis and a suitable alternative for managing transplant rejection in cases where cyclosporine or tacrolimus is not tolerated. 

Cyclosporine is commonly used for immunosuppression following transplantation to prevent organ rejection. However, it can cause side effects such as nausea, diarrhoea, and elevated liver enzymes. These symptoms are adverse effects of cyclosporine rather than indicative of treatment failure.

Azathioprine may be used as another alternative, although it is less commonly preferred due to its potential for myelosuppression.

When a patient experiences intolerable side effects with cyclosporine, tacrolimus is often used as an alternative. Tacrolimus, another effective immunosuppressant, can also cause nausea, dizziness, and dyspnea in some patients.

Other options:

Option B: Etanercept is a TNF-α antagonist used in rheumatoid arthiritis and Crohn’s disease.

Option C: Tocilizumab is an anti-IL-6 antibody that would be of little benefit following an organ transplant.

Option D: Basiliximab is an interleukin-2 receptor antagonist for activated T lymphocytes that may cause shortness of breath. As the patient has dyspnoea, the administration of basiliximab will further worsen his condition.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Ertugliflozin, which has been recently approved by the FDA, except

choices.text: It is indicated for the treatment of type I diabetes mellitus
It is a sodium glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor
It is not recommended in patients with an estimated GFR below 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2
Female genital mycotic infections are the most common among all adverse reactions

questions.solution:
• Ertugliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor indicated as an adjunct to diet and exercise to improve glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • It is not used for the treatment of type 1 diabetes mellitus or diabetic ketoacidosis.

Dosage and administration:

  • The recommended starting dose is 5 mg once daily, taken in the morning, with or without food.
  • The dosage can be increased to 15 mg once daily in those tolerating Ertugliflozin and needing additional glycemic control.
  • Do not use in patients with an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) below 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2.
  • Initiation and continued use are not recommended in patients with an eGFR persistently between 30 and less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m2.

Mechanism of action:

  • SGLT2 is the predominant transporter responsible for reabsorption of glucose from the glomerular filtrate back into the circulation.
  • Ertugliflozin is an inhibitor of SGLT2.
  • By inhibiting SGLT2, Ertugliflozin reduces renal reabsorption of filtered glucose and lowers the renal threshold for glucose, and thereby increases urinary glucose excretion.

Contraindication:

  • Severe renal impairment, end-stage renal disease, or dialysis. 
  • History of serious hypersensitivity reaction to Ertugliflozin.

Adverse reactions:

  • The most common adverse reactions associated with Ertugliflozin (incidence ≥ 5%) were female genital mycotic infections.

questions.text: A neurology resident changed the current oral medication of a patient with Alzheimer's disease to a transdermal patch of a cholinesterase inhibitor. What must be the new drug that was prescribed?
questions.solution:
Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is available as a transdermal patch for use in Alzheimer's disease. It can be applied for over 24 hours. Transdermal delivery reduces the fluctuation and avoids direct gastric irritation effects associated with oral formulations. 

Option A: Tacrine is an anticholinesterase that is obsolete because of its association with hepatotoxicity. 

Options B and D: Donepezil and galantamine transdermal formulations are under development and yet to be available in the market.

questions.text: Which of the following is available for intravenous administration for influenza B infections?
questions.solution:
Peramivir is available for intravenous administration in uncomplicated influenza B infections.

Route of administration of neuraminidase inhibitors in influenza

Zanamivir: Inhalational

Oseltamivir: Oral

Peramivir: Intravenous

Note:

Oseltamavir and Zanamavir IV formulations are only investigational at present

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease is being treated with sucralfate. Which of the following adverse effects can be seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Gastric bezoar can be seen in a patient taking sucralfate. Sucralfate produces a viscous gel that has a ‘sticky nature’. The sticky nature may be responsible for gastric bezoars, particularly in those with gastroparesis.

Sucralfate is composed of a sulfate of sucrose with Al(OH)3. It undergoes cross-linking to produce a viscous polymer that sticks to epithelial cells and ulcers in acidic environments. It inhibits hydrolysis of the mucosal proteins by pepsin.

It is used in the prophylaxis of stress ulcers, and in conditions where mucosal ulceration is not responding to acid suppression.

Adverse effects of sucralfate include constipation and bezoar formation. It may inhibit absorption of other drugs like digoxin, cimetidine, ketoconazole, and fluoroquinolone antibiotics due to the viscous layer formed in the stomach. Hence it should be taken at least 2 hours after administration if these drugs.

The other options:

Vitamin B12 deficiency and increased risk of bone fractures are side effects of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). However, their clinical significance has not been proven yet. Hypergastrinemia is more commonly seen with PPIs than H2 receptor antagonists.

questions.text: Therapeutic level of lithium (mEq/L) that is indicated for prophylaxis of mania is
questions.solution:
Therapeutic level of lithium that is indicated for prophylaxis of mania is 0.6-1.0mEq/L

Target therapeutic levels for lithium in various conditions

1.0-1.5mEq/L: Acute mania

0.6-1.0mEq/L: Prophylaxis of acute mania

0.6-1.0mEq/L: Bipolar disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is an atypical antipsychotic?
questions.solution:
Cariprazine is an atypical antipsychotic with partial agonist activity at D2 receptors and 5-HT2A receptors.

Fluphenazine, perphenazine and thioridazine are first-generation typical antipsychotics having D2 receptor antagonism activity (options a,b and d).

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately depicts the effect of ethyl alcohol on CYP2E1?

choices.text: No effect on both acute and chronic consumption

questions.solution:
Chronic consumption of ethyl alcohol results in the induction of CYP2E1 enzymes and results in faster metabolism of drugs that are dependent on CYP2E1.

Acutely, ethyl alcohol can inhibit the action of various metabolizing enzymes including CYP2E1.

questions.text: GABA transporter inhibitor among the following is
questions.solution:
Tiagabine acts by depressing GABA transporter GAT-1 that is involved in the removal of synaptically released GABA.

Vigabatrin is an inhibitor of GABA transaminase (option a).

Pregabalin and gabapentin are structurally similar to GABA but do not have any effect on GABA transporter or metabolism (options c and d).

questions.text: Sugammadex is a reversal agent for
questions.solution:
Sugammadex is a novel reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.

Sugammadex is a modified gamma-cyclodextran that binds rocuronium and vecuronium tightly and decreases the concentration of free plasma levels.

questions.text: Incorrect statement about angiotensin II is

choices.text: Used clinically to increase blood pressure in shock

questions.solution:
Angiotensin II through central action increases ADH secretion and induces thirst (option b).

Angiotensin II causes the release of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex (option d).

Angiotensin II is recently approved (2017-USFDA) for clinical use to increase blood pressure in patients with septic or other distributive shocks (option a).

questions.text: Class 1A antiarrhythmic agents block the following ion channels
questions.solution: Class 1A antiarrhythmic agents block sodium channels with moderate intensity. It also has an additional action of blockade of potassium channels that is responsible for prolonging the action potential duration.

questions.text: Choose the correct pair matching with the diagram

choices.text: A: Thiazides B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
A: Loop diuretics B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

questions.solution:
A is the loop of Henle; loop diuretics act on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. B is proximal convoluted tubule; carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act on this part.

 

 

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a TNF alpha inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Anakinra is a recombinant, non-glycosylated form of human interleukin 1A. It is approved for use in rheumatoid arthritis and for cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes (CAPS).

Infliximab, etanercept, and golimumab are TNF alpha inhibitors (options a, b and d). Adalimumab & Certolizumab are other TNF alpha inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following, acts by inhibiting the action of a transporter?
questions.solution:
Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter (OATP) in renal tubules.

Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist (option a).

Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase enzyme (option c).

Vigabatrin is a GABA transaminase inhibitor (option d).

questions.text: Metolazone belongs to the following class of diuretics
questions.solution:
Metolazone is a thiazide-like diuretic.

Points to note about metolazone:

  • Unlike other diuretics, the antihypertensive and diuretic action of metolazone is retained even in severe renal failure (GFR <15 ml/min).
  • Additional proximal tubular action has been observed.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of nicorandil in angina is/are
questions.solution:
Nicorandil has both nitrate-like (c-GMP dependent) properties and acts as an agonist of ATP-sensitive potassium channels.

Vasodilating action of nicorandil is potentiated by PDE5 inhibitors and only partially blocked by inhibitors of potassium sensitive ATP channels suggesting that both mechanisms is relevant for its action.

questions.text: Beta-blocker having potassium channel opening action
questions.solution:
Tilisolol is a third-generation non-selective beta-blocker having an additional action of opening the potassium channels.

Additional activities of 3rd generation beta-blockers:

  • α1 adrenergic receptor blockade: labetalol, carvedilol, bucindolol, bevantolol, nipradilol
  • Increased production of NO: celiprolol, nebivolol, carteolol, bopindolol, nipradolol
  • β2 agonist properties: celiprolol, carteolol, bopindolol
  • Ca2+ entry blockade: carvedilol, betaxolol, bevantolol
  • Opening of K+ channels: tilisolol
  • Antioxidant action: carvedilol

questions.text: The risk of carbamazepine induced Steven Johnson syndrome is increased in the presence of which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
HLA allele B-1502 is implicated as a marker for carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis in Han Chinese, the USFDA recommends genotyping all Asians for the allele.

Note: The HLA B*1502 allele is seen in high frequency in many Asian populations other than Han Chinese, but there are few data on whether the allele is a marker for this severe outcome in anyone other than Han Chinese.

questions.text: The most effective drug in the treatment of loa-loa is?
questions.solution:
DEC - Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for the treatment of loiasis, but it is advisable to start with a small initial dose to diminish host reactions that result from the destruction of microfilariae.

Treatment is initiated with test doses of 50 mg (1 mg/kg in children) daily for 2–3 days, escalating to maximally tolerated daily doses of 9 mg/kg in three doses for 2–3 weeks.

Glucocorticoids pretreatment may be administered to ameliorate acute reactions. In rare instances, life-threatening encephalopathy follows the treatment of loiasis, probably due to the inflammatory reaction to dead or dying microfilariae lodged in the cerebral microvasculature.

questions.text: Ibrutinib is a _______
questions.solution:
Ibrutinib is a Bruton Tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It inhibits malignant B cell proliferation - used in CLL, SLL, Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia.

Imatininib is a BCR- ABL kinase inhibitor.

Palbociclib is a CDK inhibitor approved for use in metastatic breast carcinoma.

Ruxolitinib is Jak1/2 inhibitor indicated for the treatment of patients with polycythemia vera who have had an inadequate response to hydroxyurea and for the treatment of myelofibrosis.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of alendronate is _____
questions.solution:
Alendronate, a bisphosphonate acts by direct inhibition of bone resorption. Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling, remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled, and then are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Although bisphosphonates prevent hydroxyapatite dissolution, their antiresorptive action is due to direct inhibitory effects on osteoclasts.

questions.text: Beta blockers belong to which class of antiarrhythmic drugs
questions.solution:
According to Vaughan Williams and Singh’s classification of Antiarrhythmic drugs beta blockers are included in type II.

 Class I

Membrane stabilizing agents (Na+ channel blockers)

  • Moderately decrease dv/dt of 0 phase
  • Little decrease in dv/dt of 0 phase
  • Marked decrease in dv/dt of 0 phase 
  
  • Quinidine, Procainamide, Disopyramide
  • Lidocaine, Mexiletine
  • Propafenone, Flecainide 
Class II Anti-adrenergic agents (β blockers) Propranolol, Esmolol, Sotalol (also class III) 
Class III Agents widening AP (prolong repolarization and ERP)   Amiodarone, Dronedarone, Dofetilide, Ibutilide
Class IV Calcium channel blockers Verapamil, Diltiazem
Class V Miscellaneous Digoxin, adenosine, magnesium, atropine and potassium.

questions.text: Orexin receptor antagonist indicated for insomnia is
questions.solution:
Suvorexant is the orexin receptor antagonist that is approved for use in insomnia. Orexins promote wakefulness and antagonists of orexin receptor induces sleep.

Aprepitant, rolaprepitant and netupitant are NK1 receptor antagonist used as antiemetics (options a, b and d).

questions.text: Mechanism of action of the antidiarrheal agent racecadotril is
questions.solution:
Racecadotril is a peripheral enkephalinase inhibitor.

Enkephalins are delta-opioid receptor agonists that decrease secretions. Racecadotril acts as an antisecretory agent by increasing enkephalin levels. It has minimal/no effect on motility.

Racecadotril is indicated for symptomatic treatment of diarrhea in infants and children.

questions.text: Beta-lactamase inhibitor that does not cause suicidal inhibition of beta-lactamase is
questions.solution:
Avibactam is a newer non-beta lactam beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is a non-suicidal inhibitor. Causes reversible acylation of beta-lactamase targets. Has a broader spectrum of action than suicidal inhibitors. Vaborbactam is another non-suicidal inhibitor.

Suicidal inhibitors

  • Clavulanic acid
  • Tazobactam
  • Sulbactam

questions.text: All phase II biotransformation reactions involve non-micorsomal enzymes except
questions.solution:
Glucuronidation is the only phase II biotransformation reaction that involves microsomal enzymes.

All the other phase II biotransformation reactions involve non-micorsomal enzymes (options a, b and c).

questions.text: True regarding liraglutide is _____
questions.solution:
Liraglutide is a GLP- 1 receptor agonist.

Liraglutide is a soluble fatty acid-acylated GLP-1 analog. The half-life is approximately 12 hours, permitting once-daily dosing. It is approved in patients with type 2 diabetes who achieve inadequate control with diet and exercise and are receiving concurrent treatment with metformin, sulfonylureas, or thiazolidinediones.

It reduces post-meal hyperglycemia by

  • Increasing glucose mediated insulin release
  • Lowering glucagon levels
  • Slowing gastric emptying
  • Decreasing appetite

It is used in type 2 DM and is the only GLP-1 receptor agonist used in obesity.

questions.text: Drug of choice for actinomycosis is:
questions.solution:
Penicillin G is the agent of choice for the treatment of all forms of actinomycosis.

The dose should be 18-24 million units of penicillin G intravenously per day for 6 weeks. Some physicians continue therapy for 2-3 months with oral penicillin V (500 mg four times daily). Surgical drainage or excision of the lesion may be necessary before a cure is accomplished.

Alternatively, treatment can also be done with tetracyclines.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes capillary leak syndrome?
questions.solution:
Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor(GM CSF) is known to cause capillary leak syndrome.

With prolonged administration, a few patients may develop a capillary leak syndrome, with peripheral edema and pleural and pericardial effusions.

Other drugs causing capillary leak syndrome:

  • IL 2
  • IL 4
  • Clofarabine
  • Denileukin diftitox
  • Gemcitabine

Other options: All of them are Granulocyte-colony stimulating factor analogues and do not cause capillary leak syndrome.

questions.text: The recent drug approved for the treatment of dry mouth associated with Sjogren’s syndrome is _____
questions.solution:
Cevimeline, a quinuclidine derivative of acetylcholine, is a newer direct-acting muscarinic agonist used for the treatment of dry mouth associated with Sjogren’s syndrome or caused by radiation damage of the salivary glands.

It is a synthetic M3 selective cholinomimetic drug.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about biotransformation?

choices.text: Phase I reactions unmask a functional group
Phase II reactions may precede phase I reactions
Biotransformation of drugs occurs primarily in the liver
Flavin containing monooxygenases are a part of phase 2 enzymes

questions.solution:
Flavin containing monooxygenases (FMO) are a part of Phase 1 oxidation reactions. Others are carried out by Cytochrome P450s, , aand Epoxide hydrolases(EH).

 Phase I reactions usually convert the parent drug to a more polar metabolite by introducing or unmasking/ adding a functional group such as –OH, –COOH, –SH, –O–, or NH2. Reactions carried out by phase 1 enzymes usually lead to the inactivation of a drug/activation of the drug.

Majority of the drugs undergo these biotransformation reactions in a sequential manner. However, rarely Phase II reactions may precede phase I reaction.

The biotransformation of drugs occurs primarily in the liver. Other organs with significant drug-metabolizing capacity include the GI tract, kidneys, and lungs.

questions.text: What instruction do you give to a mother who is lactating for drug use?

choices.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk
Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious
To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

questions.solution:
Ideally, the mother should feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least.

  • The drugs are present in breast milk in variable amount but lesser than in plasma of mother.
  • Breastfeeding is advised at least 3-4 hours after drug intake so that plasma concentration is lesser and hence the concentration in the breast milk is also less.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is 4.

In the above graph,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

Therapeutic index (TI) = LD50/ED50.

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: The package description of a drug states that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each unit of the tablet formulation, but in reality, each unit contains only 200mg. What is the terminology used to refer to these kinds of drugs?
questions.solution:
A drug stating that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each tablet, but contains only 200mg is a misbranded drug, according to the CDSCO (Central drugs standard control organization).

The drug and cosmetics act initially passed in 1940 and amended in 2016 provides a definition of misbranded, spurious, and adulterated drugs.

A drug is considered misbranded if it fulfills any of the following three conditions:

  • If the appearance of the drug has been altered to conceal physical damage or make it appear of greater therapeutic value than it actually is (or)
  • If it is not labeled in the prescribed manner (or)
  • If the label or container of the drug makes a false or misleading claim about the drug. In this case, the packet states that there is 500 mg of paracetamol present as opposed to the 200 mg that is actually present.

A drug is considered spurious if it fulfills the following conditions:

  • If the drug is imported under a name that belongs to another drug (or)
  • If the drug is an imitation of another drug with the intent to deceive (or)
  • If the label depicts a manufacturer that is either fictitious or a real company with no ties to the product (or)
  • If it has been substituted wholly or in part by another drug or substance.

A drug is considered adulterated if it fulfills the following conditions:

  • If it consists wholly or in part of any filthy, putrid, poisonous, or decomposed substance (or)
  • If it has been manufactured under unsanitary conditions (or)
  • If it bears a coloring other than the one prescribed (or)
  • If it has been mixed with any substance that may reduce its quality or strength.

*Note: The term counterfeit drugs is a broad term and is used by the WHO. This may also be conceived to include misbranded, spurious, or adulterated drugs. However, the term misbranded drugs would be a more appropriate answer here since it is likely that the reference used is from CDSCO.

questions.text: The loading dose of a drug is governed primarily by:
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution of the drug determines the loading dose of the drug.

Loading Dose = Vol. of distribution x Desired steady state plasma concentration.

When the time to reach a steady-state is long, as it is for drugs with long half-lives, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the target concentration.

Option A: Clearance is used to determine the maintenance dose. 

Maintenance dose = Clearance x Desired Steady-state plasma concentration.

Options C and D: Plasma half-life primarily determines the frequency of dosing, while bioavailability determines the route of administration. Though bioavailability may affect the dose necessary, it will not be the primary factor considered during the calculation of the loading dose.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients the drug of choice is doxycycline.

An alternative treatment option in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is chloramphenicol.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner?
questions.solution:
Schedule H drugs should be sold only if the prescription is from a registered medical practitioner (RMP). 

Important schedules under the “drugs and cosmetics act”: 

  • C and C1: Biological and special products
  • F and F1: Bacterial vaccines
  • G: Drugs that must be labelled with the word “caution” should not be taken without medical supervision
  • J: List of diseases and ailments which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure
  • M: Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP)
  • P: Expiry period of drug formulations
  • W: Drugs marketed under generic name only
  • X: Psychotropic drugs requiring a special license for manufacture and sale
  • Y: Requirements and guidelines on clinical trials, import, and manufacture of new drugs.

Related Pearl: Drug regulatory schedules 1940: (2016 update)

Schedule Details
Schedule C Biological and other special products e.g. Toxins, Insulin, Sera & Antibiotics.
Schedule D List of drugs exempted from the provision of import of drugs.
Schedule F

Blood and blood products

F I - Production of Bacterial vaccines, Anti- Sera

F II - Specification of standards for Surgical dressing

FF- Specification of standard Ophthalmic preparation
Schedule G With a label of Caution, dangerous to use except under medical supervision.
Schedule H Prescription drugs.
Schedule J List of diseases that a drug may not prevent or cure. Eg - HIV & Atherosclerosis
Schedule M Regulations regarding good manufacturing practices
Schedule P Regulations regarding the life period and storage of various drugs.
Schedule W Drugs marketed under generic names.
Schedule X Drugs having abuse and dependence liability.
Schedule Y Requirement and guidelines for import/ manufacture or Clinical trials in India

questions.text: Which of the following shows a U-shaped dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
Vitamins and essential metals show a U-shaped dose-response curve.

At a low dose, adverse effects are observed because there is a deficiency of these nutrients to maintain homeostasis. As dose increases, homeostasis is achieved, and the bottom of the U-shaped dose-response curve is reached. As the dose increases to surpass the amount required to maintain homeostasis, toxicity can ensue.

Thus, adverse effects are seen at both low and high doses. 

Hockey stick-shaped dose-response curve for toxicants that are also metabolic by-products. 

Inverted U-shaped dose-response curve for ligands that downregulate their receptors.
